page.title: 13RIVERS COLN AND CHURN
page.content: {River Churn {The Seven Springs}are where the{River {Churn}starts.The Springs were thought to be the source of the{Thames.}The Churn joins the{Thames}at Cricklade.It is about 30 km. long.It is not certain how the{Churn}got it's name but since 1540 it has been known as the{Churn. {River Coln} The Colns source is in the hills above Brockhampton .It flows for 41 km. through green meadows, steep valleys, wooded hills to join the Thames at the Round House near Lechlade.People are not certain why it is called the Coln; it has been known by many different names.Around the Withington area it forms part of the parish boundary and used to be known as the Tilmoth.The Coln was used for turning the Mill Wheel.Both rivers are fished for trout.
